unnormalised: Okay, buckle up, ladies (and gentlemen who bravely venture into the world of Obstetrics & Gynecology!), because we're about to embark on a journey through pregnancy, childbirth, and everything else south of the border. And yes, there will be TMI. Consider yourself warned!
normalised: Okay, buckle up, ladies (and gentlemen who bravely venture into the world of Obstetrics and Gynecology!), because we're about to embark on a journey through pregnancy, childbirth, and everything else south of the border. And yes, there will be T-M-I. Consider yourself warned!

unnormalised: First things first, let's talk about the joy of early pregnancy symptoms. Forget that glow everyone raves about, I was rocking the "permanently seasick" look for a solid 3 months. Morning sickness? More like all-day-and-night sickness! I swear, I could smell my neighbour’s sambar from 2 km away and instantly feel nauseous. My doctor, Dr. Nair, bless her soul, just chuckled and prescribed ginger biscuits. Turns out, ginger biscuits and constant naps were my new best friends. Pro-tip: Keep a stash of biscuits *everywhere*.

unnormalised: Then there's the whole "finding out the gender" thing. We went for the 20-week ultrasound (around 20 wks) at Cloudnine Hospital. The technician, bless her cotton socks, asked if we wanted to know. My husband, Rakesh, immediately shouted "YES!" before I could even form a coherent sentence. Turns out, it's a girl! Rakesh promptly burst into tears, which, let's be honest, was pretty adorable. Cue the frantic saree shopping and brainstorming for names. We finally settled on "Aisha."

unnormalised: Let's not forget the joys of childbirth! I opted for an epidural (best decision ever, BTW). Labor lasted for 12 hrs (approx), and let me tell you, those last few hours felt like an eternity. The nurses were amazing, though. They kept telling me to push like I was birthing a watermelon. Watermelon? Seriously? I felt like I was birthing an entire *fruit salad*! But hey, Aisha arrived safe and sound, weighing in at 3.2 kg.

unnormalised: Postpartum life is a whole other level of crazy. Sleep deprivation is a very real thing. And let's just say, I now have a newfound appreciation for the power of dry shampoo and oversized t-shirts. My wardrobe now consists of 90% comfy clothes and 10% "maybe I'll wear this again someday" outfits. Also, I can now change a diaper in under 30 seconds. It's a skill I never knew I needed, but hey, life is full of surprises!

unnormalised: And the unsolicited advice? Oh my god, the unsolicited advice! Everyone and their ajji has an opinion on how you should raise your child. From breastfeeding versus formula (I breastfed for 6 months, FYI) to co-sleeping versus cribs, the opinions are endless. My advice? Smile, nod, and then do whatever the heck works best for you and your baby. You're the mom, you know best (most of the time, anyway!).

unnormalised: So there you have it, a (slightly) humorous glimpse into the world of obstetrics and gynecology. It's messy, it's exhausting, and it's definitely not always glamorous. But it's also the most rewarding experience of my life. Now, if you'll excuse me, I need to go change a diaper and drink approximately 5 cups of chai. Wish me luck!
